THE NEWS-LETTER.
Vol. VI.

DECEMBER 18, 1901.

No. 6.

MY COLLEGE DAYS,
FTER several years participation in lacrosse, baseball, football, and
college athletics in general, I can say without the slightest hesitation
that I consider lacrosse the most fascinating game played, both from
the standpoint of the player, and from that of the spectator. The Indians, who
were the originators of this game, displayed unwonted sagacity in inventing a
form of exercise which tends to develop all the qualities of the perfect athlete,—
muscular prowess, speed, agility, dexterity, and together with these physical at
tributes, quick mental perception as well. The charm for the individual player
is far in excess of that afforded by either baseball or football, because of the continual excitement and uncertainty under which the player labors in never knowing where the next play is going to be. There is far more scientific individual
play in lacrosse than in any other usual collegiate game, and it eliminates to a
great extent the ULTRA dangerous element of football. Perhaps I am a trifle
prejudiced in its favor, but I repeat that I consider it the very best form of exercise. All this is the player's side of it; but from the spectator's point of view
I consider it the most interesting because of the open work which permits a
close observance of the game in all its details.
Though the game is being developed at more American colleges every year,
the one reason why it has not yet superseded baseball is because it is not an
American sport. It is a Canadian game, and baseball is a native American
game. Therefore the American colleges, like Hopkins, C. C. N. Y., Stevens,
Lehigh, etc., which have always kept the lacrosse standard on a high level, will
find it hard to induce the other colleges to adopt it at the expense of football.
Still, it has grown, and will, I think, continue to grow in popularity.
During my entire career at the City College of New York, I engaged in all
athletic 'sports,—baseball, football, and lacrosse; and in my graduating year
Was captain of the lacrosse team, succeeding Jack Curry, who, I believe, once
coached Hopkins. Our team that year won the championship, and many of
Our League games were veritable "hair-raisers." In our game with Lehigh we
were defeated, and previous to that game the New York Athletic Club had
beaten Lehigh, so, going by comparative scores, we seemed predestined to defeat
when our turn came to play N. Y. A. C. I remember the game perfectly as one
of the fastest and best contested I ever played, and only by the hardest kind of
work did we succeed in scoring, thus defeating our rivals by the score of one to
nothing. It was flattering for me to note that on the All American lacrosse
team of 1891-92, were four of my men.
44

2

THE NEWS—LETTER.

Several times I have played against Stevens, and I must say I found them
rather rough in their style of play. My position on the lacrosse team was first
defense.
I have met several men who have contributed largely to the success of lacrosse in Baltimore. Mr. Maddren, who, I have heard, "made" lacrosse at
Hopkins, I met during his connection with the Crescents, and I became acquainted with the five Penniman boys in 1895, when, as a delegate to a convention at the Hopkins, I visited Baltimore for the first time.
Victor Mapes, who wrote my version of "Don Caesar's Return" was a Columbia man of great athletic standing, holding the American Intercollegiate
hurdle and broad jump records, His broad jump record of 22 feet 6 inches, was
only recently broken. In 1891 Mapes was president of the American Intercollegiate Athletic Association, and I was treasurer; so it seems quite a coincidence
that he and I should be associated now in our life work as we were in college
days.
After graduating from the City College of New York I entered the New
York School of Law. The same year I captained the Law School football team,
playing, at different times, end and half back Incidentally I may state that, as
far as I am aware, I was the first man to wear a rubber nose-guard on the football field. It was in a game with Fordham, where I was lined up against a
big fellow, that I donned it for the first time. I found it extremely satisfactory,
inasmuch as I was spared the pain of a broken nose, though I must confess that
nose-guard felt awkward at first, and the astonishment created among both players and spectators was really amusing. It was in the same year, 1892, in a
game against Rutgers that I sustained a severe injury which confined me to the
hospital for two months, and it was during this period that I finally determined
upon the stage as my life career.
College dramatics always proved of much interest to me, and I always entered into them with great spirit. We had a strong number of men at the C.
C. N. *Y., who showed histrionic ability, and our efforts were generally successful. Not only did we have plenty of sport getting up plays, but the real
advantage as training for the stage was remarkable. The benefits derived from
a college dramatic society are well worth any trouble necessary in organization.
Besides the college dramatic society to which I belonged, I was also a member
of nearly every amateur club in New York for five years.
In addition to the academic training afforded by my college career, I consider the time spent there as valuable in laying a broad foundation for my life
work, and I look back upon my college days as pleasant and well spent.''

JAMES K. HACKETT.
THE PERSECUTION OF MAN.
—

t

HE powers of Smith College have shown a remarkable amount of acuteness
and ability to understand human nature in the means they have adopted
to abate, the male nuisance at the college.
There had existed a mutual admiration society between the good looking
young ladies at Smith and the good looking young men at Amherst, which re-

THE NEWS-LETTER.

3

suited in the almost eternal presence of Amherst men inside the walls of the
young ladies' seminary, not to mention innumerable little walks, and cozy little
theatre parties of two. Every Saturday and Sunday the halls of the Smith
homes were "converted into reception rooms for Amherst fellows," so that the
work for Monday—and other days—was neglected, in the pursuit of social
pleasures. Of course the education of young women should be on more serious
lines than these, so the faculty thought stringent laws were necessary. A set
of rules were consequently drawn up, which are destined to put an end to all
these frivolities. All walks, talks, and those cozy little theatre parties of two
will have to be abandoned, unless the girl is engaged to the fellow. The penalty
certainly is severe, but as students of human nature, we very much fear that the
parties concerned will not consider it in this light. It is extremely difficult for
certain people to realize the value of careful oversight by one's elders and
betters.
Later notice from Massachusetts Twenty engagements of Smith girls to
Amherst men were announced this week.

SCHOLARS AS ATHLETES.
HE prominence of athletics as a fundamental feature in college life has
grown ste dily the last few years. Probably the most patent reason for
this advancement, and the liberal acknowledgement of athletics by college
authorities, is the interest taken in sports by the scholastically inclined as well
as by the so called "athletes." Each year the records show a large number of
men carrying off academic honors, and winning athletic glory at the same time.
Here at Hopkins a glance will suffice to support this statement; some of the
best men on the football, track, and lacrosse teams are honor men, and leaders of
their respective classes. At Columbia, last year, the report of the dean showed
that twenty prominent athletes were among those receiving high academic
honors, and at all the other colleges statistics point the same way. The reason
for this is apparent, and is powerfully stated in the famous definition of education given by Thomas Huxley.
"That man, I think, has had a liberal education, who has been so trained
in his youth that his body is the ready servant of his will and does with ease
and pleasure all the work that, as a mechanism, it is capable of; whose intellect
is a clear, cold, logic engine, with all its parts of equal strength, and in smooth
working order; ready, like a steam engine, to be turned to any kind of work,
and spin the gossamers as well as forge the anchors of the mind; whose mind
is stoied with a knowledge of the great and fundamental truths of nature and
of the laws of her operations; one, who no stunted ascetic, is full of life and
fire, but whose passions are trained to come to heel by a vigorous will, the
servant of a tender conscience; who has learned to love all beauty, whether of
nature or of art, to hate all vileness, and to respect others as himself."

THE AFORESAID.
NCE there was a Time when this University had not Yet been moved to
Homewood, because the last Thirty-Nine cents of an Endowment was
Hard to Raise from the people of Baltimore. During this Period there
existed In Two Classes of the University a Feeling that each one was Better
than the Other, and it was often demonstrated that Such was the Case.
The facts were that One of these Classes had been Hauled over the Rough
Road of Book learning for a Year, while the other was a Young Infant, and had
just entered the Race for Knowing Things. For this reason the Former imagined
that they were Hellers ad Libitum of the Neighborhood, and that the Other Class
should do Fealty to Them; consequently, a spirit of Hostility Existed until Something had to be Decided. There being a Precedent that Such Feelings should be
settled by a Football game, and in Case Some were alive after this was Over, a
Cane rush should be instituted whereby the Rest might be killed without anyone
being Arrested for Manslaughter. These Classes decided that it was Up to Them
to do This.
When the Seventh Day of December, being the appointed time for the Killme quick, had arrived, the Junior Aggregate feeling that They were too much of a
Second-to-None to be Hauled on the Baltimore Consolidated, procured the money
somehow to Hire a Bus, or, maybe it is not Paid for yet; we don't know. It is
said, that the Freshmen were actuated by an Impulse to do the Same, but That
was All. Anyhow, they all got There.
Before any definite Steps of Procedure were taken, Both teams let their
Phisiognomies be Photographed, so that Mother might see how Brave her Boy
looked before he was Served up to her on a Stretcher. After this they Backed
up opposite each other, and got Ready to do Biz. The Junior team felt from the
Beginning that they were to be Leading Lady during the whole Matinee, and went
at it in a King Midas sort of Way that suggested that Every time they Landed,
Touchdowns could be Seen.
But there was One among the Other Team who had Some Nerve with him and
was Willing to Work. The Rest of the Team felt that He would give them a
happy Issue out of All their afflictions if he Could, and Helped him with all their
Heart. There were, on the Other hand,some ancient Aniniases among the Junior
Team, who could identify Themselves as Handlers of the Pigskin as it Should be
Handled, and inteuded to Go Way up behind the Goal posts with the Ball and Sit
down, when they Felt like it.
Alas, for these Gridiron Terrors! One Ham Jr. had rubbed some kind of
Salve into the oval,till it was Greasy as a Yard of Free Lunch,and had a Tendency
to play Hide and Seek with itself. The Juniors were frequently "It."
During the first Half both Teams avoided the Goal Posts with such Precision
that when time was Up there were no Touchdowns pinned to the Jackets of Either.
But in the second Semi, the Juniors saw that their Reputation was at Stake, and
began to Pass the Pigskin up the Line at a frequent Rate, till two Touchdowns
and almost a Third was the Result of their Rushes. When the Agony was Over,

O

THE NEWS—LETTER.

5

the Junior Ensemble could count Twelve Points for themselves, and the Freshites gave Evidence of That tired Feeling, and seemed to be Satisfied.
In the Meantime, one of the Ancient order of Cop, with a Paunch that
Helped-to make Milwaukee-famous, had a Bad Dream, and began to do some
Duty on a Junior who had done Nothing, and said to him, Come with Me.
When this Ward-heeler reached the Station with his Victim, amid Shouts of
derision, which didn't seem to Phrase him, He was Told that he Bore about the
same relation to the Force as the Appendix does to the Human Anatomy, and it
was True. The Prisoner had now Become a Hero, and had Sympathy served up
to him in large Hunks. Maidens in the Grandstand Heaved heavy Sighs, Rolled
their Eyes Heavenward, and Said, Poor Mr. Bryan; isn't Thatjust Awful!
But the Cane rush couldn't be Stopped on his Account, and the two Classes
faced each other Desperately, with a Sigh of Regret that Such indeed was the Case.
When the whistle Blew, the Carnage began, and Many a Spectator's Soul
within him Burned to see the Exploits of those so Young. They Connected with
a Crash, and many a Wretch at the Bottom of the Heap was heard to Curse unseen, and waste his Profanity on the Desert Air. Some who were so Unfortunate
as to Ring in a Little Late, leaped around on top of the Heap and Dished out
Courageous Words to their mates Below.
When enough Time was given for Those Underneath to be planted in Soil
and to Realize what a H— on Earth was, the whistle Blew again, to Show that
it was All over and the Ambulance Corps was in Order.
Later, it was Found that Eleven hands gripped the cane. Nine of these were
Traced to Grease Spots in the Ground,which were Analyzed and found to Contain
the Essential Elements of Juniority. The other two were Followed to a wisp of
Hair in the Soil, and found by a Reductio ad Absurdum to have Originally grown
on the Pate of the Dickey bird. Now that It was Over, everybody seemed to be
Happy again, and, with the Exception of two or three Stray ears, and a Sprinkling of Teeth—which were Identified and Claimed—nobody was Hurt, and all
were glad that Some one had Won. Happy youth who could Say that he was
three layers Deep under the Cane, and would have had a Hand on it if —. But
the details are Many.
The Victors again Mounted their Haul-me-Home and Travelled down the
Street, giving Everybody the Glad Glance, while the Vanquished were Happy to
Hear themselves Praised by Female admirers, and the Dickey bird could have
Had Several feminine Hearts to Do as he Pleased with if Some overheard Snags
of Conversation were Correct.
On the Whole no one was Sorry that he had been There. It was Suggested
that the Absence of a Coin grabber at the gate would Account for the numerousness of Wistful Watchers present, but Anyone who brought Friends with him
would say This was a Lie, if you accused him of It.
Moral. Freshmen—Eat Mellen's Food and grow Strong.
Juniors—Bluff them now for it is your last Chance.
Seniors—Ignore both.
L. C. M. '02.

T HAS become almost a daily occurrence to read of the vast sums of money
given away in this country for the purpose of endowing colleges. Only
last week we were astonished to read of an offer, made by Andrew Carnegie, of ten million dollars for the purpose of founding a National University,
and the very same paper informed us that the total value of gifts made by Mrs.
Stanford, to Leland Stanford University, amounted to twenty-five millions.
While we congratulate the latter University upon its good fortune, we cannot
but feel somewhat grieved over the apparent indifference manifested by Baltimoreans toward the Johns Hopkins University. Nearly a year ago two public
spirited gentlemen of this city presented our University with a valuable tract of
land, to be used as a site for new buildings, upon the condition that an endowment fund of one million dollars be raised. As yet this money has not been
forthcoming in spite of all the efforts made by the President and Trustees of the
University, to appeal to the generosity, public spirit, and patriotism of Marylanders, and especially Baltimoreans. These citizens seem utterly blind to the
fact that by aiding the University they will be advancing their own interests,
and furthering the cause of humanity and civilization. The Johns Hopkins
University is to-day a source of untold wealth and honor to this city and this
state, and yet take away the support of a few of our loyal and most devoted
supporters—a handful of men who have given their time, talents, and money to
the furtherance of higher education at our University—and we might as well be
on the other side of the ocean for all the interest taken in us, and encouragement and aid given us by the rest of Baltimore. Truly a "prophet is not with-

out honor save in his own country," and the Johns Hopkins University, esteemed and respected by Europe, and most of America, is treated with indifference, and coldly refused support by Maryland.

HE NEWS-LETTER calls special attention to the leading article in this issue,

Z

by the, famous American actor, Mr. James K. Hackett. During Mr.
Hackett's recent visit to Baltimore, as "Don Caesar de Bazan," he very
kindly consented to furnish us with a leading article relative to his college days,
and more particularly to his athletic career, while at the C. C. N. Y. This
article, by one who has been an all-round athlete, and who has excelled in lacrosse
and football, cannot fail to interest the student body. Mr. Hackett, with his
superb physique, manly bearing, and frank cordiality, is one of the finest types
of the American college man; a representative of that class of college men who,
of late years, have brought themselves to the very top of the ladder in every
calling. Moreover Mr. Hackett possesses in abundance that most admirable
quality, college spirit, for, notwithstanding the fact that he has been out of college, and deeply engrossed in his dramatic work for nearly ten years, his college days are not forgotten, and to-day he discusses with vivacity and interest
the lacrosse and foot ball battles he fought and won ten years ago. So we take
pleasure in presenting our readers with an article by him who to-day stands in
the foremost rank of the world's actors, and who is perhaps almost as well
known by the name of Rudolph Rassendyl as by his own name, James K.
Hackett.
T LAST forensic interest at Hopkins has manifested itself to the point of
intercollegiate debates. The question has been agitated a number of
times but never before has it taken definite shape. Now it is highly
probable that next spring will witness, besides our annual Junior-Senior
debate, a debate with some university of recognized standing, perhaps the
University of South Carolina. There is every reason in the world why Hopkins should indulge in these debating contests, just as all other colleges do;
but at the same time it is equally important that the adversary we choose
should be a first-class college or university—a foe, in every sense, worthy of
our steel. Our failure in the past to arouse sufficient interest among the student
body to enable us to participate in intercollegiate debates, has been the cause of
some wonder and comment among other colleges. This year our undergraduate
department has evinced a desire to inaugurate the plan. It is an excellent idea,
and should receive the hearty support of both faculty and students. Hopkins
certainly produces debating talent qualified to meet that of any other university. Already we have received a number of proposals to debate for colleges
and universities, north and south, and it only remains for us to use discrimination in choosing an antagonist.

HE NEWS-LETTICR submits to its readers the following letter, and asks for
an expression of opinion upon the subject. The writer appears to be
justified in his objection to "piling up," and though we have not considered the matter deeply, we think his suggestion good.

t

To THE NEWS-LETTER.

MR. EDITOR:
Can you suggest through the columns of your paper a substitute for our annual canerush; something by means of which future Junior and Freshman classes may be enabled
to work off their exuberant spirits. Last year, and year before last, I participated in the
rush, and this year, being a Senior, I looked on. From both observation and experience
(for both years I happened to be near the bottom of the pile) I am of the opinion that,
owing to the number of students which participate in it, the annual cane-rush is too dangerous a sport to be continued. Two years ago the president of our class had two ribs
broken in the rush, this year the president of the Freshman class was picked up unconscious, and such injuries will frequently result when some seventy or eighty men are piled
up on one another in a writhing, struggling mass. It is absolutely necessary to have some
general melee in which all members of both classes may participate, but why not substitute
something which will not necessitate nearly a hundred men piling upon one another, for
those at the bottom must suffer. I would suggest ;a flag-fight which would be just as spirited, last a little longer, contain all the elements of a class "scrap," and still avoid the
piling-up of an organized cane rush. What is the opinion of the student body?
A SENIOR.

ITHIN the next few weeks there will be at least one vacancy, and perhaps two or three, upon the staff of editors, and these vacancies will be
filled from the Junior and Freshman classes. We strongly urge that
those men desiring a place upon the paper, begin handing in specimens of their
work at once. These should be in the form of accounts of concerts or games,
original matter, or any items of university news which may interest the student
body. The Freshman class in particular we urge to exert themselves along
this line.

TO AN OLD PHOTOGRAPH.
'Tis through a mist of years I gaze at thee,
Sweet vision of the days that are no more,
While mem'ries fond and fancies odd and free
Breathe softly from the old times' golden shore.
I seem to hear thy voice so sweet and true,
To feel the tender pressure of thy hands,
And see the lovelight in those -eyes of blue
That speak of azure skies in far-off lands.
Ohl heart of hearts, would that thou now were here
To cast thy spell of love o'er ev'ry fear,
To guide my soul from earth's dark, dreary way,
From sorrow's night to hope's bright dawning day.
R. F. C., '02.

Elgin R. L. Gould, Ph. D. of the University in 1886, has been placed on
the slate for City Chamberlain of New York under the Low administration. Dr. Gould has done fine work for Low in his two campaigns; in
the recent one he was treasurer of the Committee on Finance, and collected over
$160,000 for the campaign fund. Dr. Gould is independent in politics.
Dr. George B. Shattuck, of the geological department, is president of the
newly organized Field Foray Club, the purpose of which is the study of the
natural and geological history of Maryland and adjoining regions. The 341
members of the club are mostly public school teachers taking the University extension lectures at the Hopkins.
Friday night, December 20, Dr. W. H. Tolman, director of the New York
Museum of Social Economy, will deliver a lecture in McCoy Hall on "Social
and Industrial Betterment," under the auspices of the Woman's Club of Roland
Park.
Dr. Remsen has been invited to make the leading address at the laying of
the corner stones of the two new buildings now being erected at Caylor University, Waco, Texas.
Ira Remsen, '97, Dr. Remsen's elder son, has made a hit in Paris by a portrait of the Marquis Ito, of Japan, who was recently published in the "Monde
illusive." The Marquis considered the likeness so excellent that he wrote a
Japanese poem to accompany it,besides signing the portrait in English, Chinese,
and Japanese characters. Mr. Remsen has lately returned to Paris, to resume
his art work there, from a year's service in the U. S. A. in the Philippines.
Dr. J. H. Hollander was in Boston on the .2th and 13th, for the purpose of
addressing the National Civil Service Reform League on the subject of "Insular
Civil Service." He was much missed by his undergraduate class in Economics.
Dr. D. C. Gilman has been re-elected President of the Civil Service Reform
League in New York.
At the annual banquet of the New England Alumni Association, held in
Boston last Saturday night, there were present from the University President
Remsen, Ex-President Gilman, and Dr. J. H. Hollander.
Elliott Strouse, '02, has left the University and has gone to Indiana, to
recuperate from an attack of sickness.
Eben C. Hill, '02, is recovering from a severe attack of pleurisy and typhoid
fever. He is at present free from the fever, but is left very weak by it, and will
not be out for a month.

10

THE NEWS-LETTER.
MUSICAL CLUBS.

DN December 13 the annual concert of the Musical Clubs, at Hannah Moore
Academy, took place. The only appearances preceding this had been at
the Hospital, November 30, and at St. Mary's Parish, Roland Park, on
December 6th, so that the occasion was, as always, very enjoyable. The feature of the evening was the soloists and the duet: T. K. Gillman, of the Medical School, bass solos; S. T. Mason, '02. humorous bass solos; W. B. Carver,
G., tenor solos; and a vaudeville duet by C. S. Hodges, '98, and S. T. Mason,
which was the hit of the evening, successfully "rough-housing" the audience.
All the clubs showed up well, especially the Banjo club; and with some hard
work, the performance on the Christmas trip ought to be creditable.
After the concert a sumptuous feed was demolished, and then the reception
began. Although said one hour, it seemed scarcely ten minutes before the sad
news came that the car was waiting.

O

For the Christmas trip, the Clubs have adopted the following schedule:
Charlestown, Thursday, December 26; Winchester, Va., Friday; Hagerstown,
Saturday. The start will be made at 7.20 A. M. Thursday, on a special car of
the B. & 0. R. R. Returning, the Clubs will leave Hagerstown by the Western Maryland R. R., at 4 P. M., Sunday, December 29. The Charlestonians
have already arranged to give the Clubs a dance after their concert, and entertainment is expected at the other places named,

THE DEBATING TEAMS.
HE annual inter-class debate for which the seniors and juniors are beginning to prepare, promises to be of unusual interest. Both bodies contain
debaters of no little ability, and, whatever the question, the arguments
should be exceptionally good. Those men who have entered their names as
candidates for the senior and junior teams are:
Seniors—Harvey B. Stone, Charles Ma/ken, John G. Campbell, Ross M.
Diggs, J. R. Pels, B. Swayne Putts, Guggenheimer, Murphy, McGlone, Wolman, Kirk, Strouse and Myers.

Juniors—Harry K. Tootle, Sol Blum, Harry W. Plaggemeyer, W. Sellman
Bird, Hoffman, Stubenrauch, Custis, Winternitz, Glocker, Strayer, Combs,
Sparrow, Addison, Adler, Dochez and Meeks.
The general topic of the debate will be "Trusts," and at each meeting of
the Senate and of the House of Representatives, some phase of the question will
he discussed. In this manner the subject will be presented from every possible
point of view, and the arguments in the final debate certainly should not be
lacking either in quantity or in quality. The freshmen are busily preparing for
their oratorical contest. Those men who are trying for positions are Austrian,
Branham, Buckler, Cator, Dickey, Emig, Kinnane, Louis, Opie, Rosenheim,
Wallis, Humrichhouse, Branch, Gutman, Cohen, Geiger, Lloyd, McGlone,

AMONG THE COLLEGES.
ALE cleared $70,000 on her foot ball season.

P

Mr. Richard Sheldon whose work on Yale's track team, of which he was
captain, has given him fame all over this country, has been compelled, through
sickness, to retire from college.
In addition to general dramatic productions, both Yale and Harvard have
two or three plays a year in French and German by students in these departments.
The Yale Musical Clubs this year number about 65 men. The clubs have
so far had a successful season, both from the musical and financial points of
view.
A new and excellent regulation at I,eland Stanford University limits the
number of women students to 500.
Of 11,000 living graduates of Yale, 9000 were present at the recent Bi-centennial, representing classes from 1850 to 1901. This is the same spirit which
prompted about fifty Hopkins men to brave the rain and wind in order to witness a championship foot ball game!
The New York Tribune gives the following selection for an All-American
football team: Center, Holt, of Yale; guards, Warner, of Cornell, and Barnard,
of Harvard; tackles, Cutts, of Harvard, and Bunker, of West Point; ends,
Henry, of Princeton, and Davis, of Princeton; quarter-back, Daly of West
Point; half-backs, Weekes, of Columbia, and Kernan, of Harvard; full back,
Graydon, of Harvard. This gives Harvard four men, Yale one, Princeton two,
West Point two, Cornell one, and Columbia one.

HE Johns Hopkins Athletic Association has awarded the honorary athletic
"H" to the following men, all of whom participated in championship
football games: Messrs. Gillespie, captain; P. Hill, Garwood, Yearley,
Campbell, Bacon, Houghton, Bernheim, Sayler, Faris, Blanck, and Sharretts.

LACROSSE OUTLOOK.
OW that the football season is over, the men -left from last year's team
and the "young hopefuls," who are to become members of this year's
lacrosse team, are coming out for practice in stick work and running.
The formation of the three cornered league with Hopkins, Lehigh, and Swarthmore as its members urges the men on all the more, and the outlook is rather
cheerful.
Among the old men who remain are Abercrombie, our star center; Captain
Schmeisser who can be relied upon to do his best at point; H. P. Straus whose
experience were the most valuable in assisting the new men to learn how to
play the game; Bertram Bernheim will again have opportunity to show how he
P. Bernheim and Abercrombie can perfect their
and Putts can shout goals;
midfield play; Ernest Schmeisser will show marked development, and together
with Tough will give their opponents a lively tussle—these men are the two
youngest members of the team, but the showing made by them last year was
most creditable and would have done justice to old men.
Among the men who have had some experience and who are trying hard
from the team, are: Frank Iglehart, J. G. Custis. J. W. Bryan, Horace Gillespie, Fred. Blanck, W. S. Bird and H. B. Stone.
During the Christmas holidays, light work will be indulged in. After the
men are again settled down to work, regular practice, four times a week, will
begin, and when spring time comes daily out of door practice will be held.

"I wint to our naytional capitol," answered Mr. Dooley, ''to confer about th: liquor-licence law with my frind Roosenfelt who, f'r all his German Jew name, is a good American. I had a gr-rand time comin' home, Hinnissy." Mr. Dooley indulged in several moments of inward reminesence.
"What was that?," asked Mr. Hennessy finally and with impatience.
"It was at th' Confederit Bazaar in Baltimore, th' town where th' Irish
elemint stharted th' civil war-r be hur-rling bricks an' roohn' mayterials upon

"Baltimore!," exclaimed Mr. Hennessy, "an' how did ye git there?'
"I fell off th' rear car 'o th' exhileratin' B. & 0. express," explained Mr.
Dooley apologetically, "an was picked up be a switchman."
"Where am I at?," I shrieked, afther wakin' up.
"Baltimore," he says. Gracious heavins, thinks I, an' Noo York on'y a

hundred an' ninety miles away.
"Whin does th' nixt thrain leave?," I demanded iv him.
"In six hours," he says. "Two thrains daily." Well, there I was, whin
I bethought me iv me couzin, Bridgit Callahan,—a descindint iv wan iv th'
sivin hundher Kings iv Ireland, but forced be penury an want to take in

"Why, cousin Dooley," she says, "you're jist in time. I'm goin to th'
Confederit Bazaar."
"Th' whaat?," I asks.
"'Tis a fair," she says, ''f'r erectin a monimint to a noble, but a lost
cause," she says, "I suppose ye have some money with ye."
"It's a losin' game, thin?," says I.
"'Tis charity," she says.
"I'll go," says I, with faith an' hope, but me pocket book sank.
An we wint. 'Twas a gr-rand sight. The noble hall was lined with
thirteen booths, stands, bars, or what ye will. 'Tis an unlucky number, I
thought, as I felt me loose change shrink instinctively fr'm me graasp. A
luvely creature come thrippin' up to me, an says:
"Don't ye waant to buy some cigareets?"
"I have no vices," I replys with some dignity.
"Too bad," she fhips back, oglin' me with wan eye. Hinnissy, I sighed.
"Go hack home, pretty wan," says I, takin' a pack. I gave thim to a small
boy nixt me an' told him to make himsilf sick all to wanct, an' th' sooner th'
betther, f'r th' glory iv young America."
"Ye were encouragin' vice," remarked Mr. Hennessy severely.
'Not so, Hinnissy, I beleeve with Maxim in increasin' th' velocity iv th'
projayctil. Mr. Hennessy looked unconvinced, but Mr. Dooley continued.

SANTA CLAUS HEARS FROM A FRESHMAN.
EVERAL days ago the NEWS-LETTER was fortunate enough to get hold
of one of the letters which the freshmen are now sending to Santa Claus.
We feel sure that its contents will interest most of our readers.

p

DEAR SANTA CLAUS:
I have almost reached the age when boys stop writing you a list of their
wants, but there are several things I want particular bad this Christmas, and
I'm going to write to you once more. Since this time last year I've been through
some fearful trials and hardships. I worked hard all the spring and managed
to pass enough examinations to get in the Johns Hopkins University. I
thought it was grand. You know it makes you feel fine to go to Hopkins.
(There are a crowd of fellows there, though, who haven't the first rudiments of
common politeness, and instead of welcoming me in a hospitable manner, they
treated me like a little yellow dog.)
I went down there to study, and didn't propose to stand for any roughhouse, but they made me take off my hat,—sometimes my shoes, pushed me
head first out of the elevator, forced me to buy chocolate at the slot ma-

THE NEWS-LETTER.

16

chine, and insisted upon making me do the hoola-hoola dance on the trophyroom table. Now you know that wasn't fair. It wasn't wright.
Upon entering the university, I considered myself a man, and felt that I
ought to shave; so I bought a mug and put it in the barber shop. The nasty,
mean things took it, and a few days afterward, made me stand on the lockers
under the gymnasium, lather one of my fellow classmen out of my own mug,
and shave him with the butt end of a golf stick. Then he shaved me the same
way. I was so angry I most cried. But what could I do with the horrid
creatures jeering at me and telling me not to whimper?
These are only a few of the mean tricks, hut I think they are enough to
make you pity me and put what I want in my stocking.
I am awful anxious to wear a black and blue jersey, hut haven't dared to
do it yet; for I saw the juniors jerk one off a fellow's back so fast that I thought
his arms would come too. After Christmas, though, I think they will let us
wear them, so please bring me one. I wear boy's size, No. 22.
I really think I am big enough to begin smoking, but hardly know whether
it would be healthy for me or not. You might bring me a pipe and I'll wait a
few weeks before using it. I also want a cow bell for Christmas. Next year I
am going to ask you to bring me a cane. Please bring me these, Santa Claus.
I haven't had a very good time since September.
A FRESHMAN.
The unfortunate freshman who wrote the above can hardly be blamed for
saying that the treatment received at the hands of the juniors was not "wright."
He has evidently been one of the marks.
We are glad to know that he is "awful anxious" to wear a black and blue
jersey, and hope he will not be molested after Christmas for so doing.
Let him take hope in the thought that better times are coming.

THE NEWS-LETTER.
Vol. VI.

DECEMBER 18, 1901.

No. 6.

MY COLLEGE DAYS,
FTER several years participation in lacrosse, baseball, football, and
college athletics in general, I can say without the slightest hesitation
that I consider lacrosse the most fascinating game played, both from
the standpoint of the player, and from that of the spectator. The Indians, who
were the originators of this game, displayed unwonted sagacity in inventing a
form of exercise which tends to develop all the qualities of the perfect athlete,—
muscular prowess, speed, agility, dexterity, and together with these physical at
tributes, quick mental perception as well. The charm for the individual player
is far in excess of that afforded by either baseball or football, because of the continual excitement and uncertainty under which the player labors in never knowing where the next play is going to be. There is far more scientific individual
play in lacrosse than in any other usual collegiate game, and it eliminates to a
great extent the ULTRA dangerous element of football. Perhaps I am a trifle
prejudiced in its favor, but I repeat that I consider it the very best form of exercise. All this is the player's side of it; but from the spectator's point of view
I consider it the most interesting because of the open work which permits a
close observance of the game in all its details.
Though the game is being developed at more American colleges every year,
the one reason why it has not yet superseded baseball is because it is not an
American sport. It is a Canadian game, and baseball is a native American
game. Therefore the American colleges, like Hopkins, C. C. N. Y., Stevens,
Lehigh, etc., which have always kept the lacrosse standard on a high level, will
find it hard to induce the other colleges to adopt it at the expense of football.
Still, it has grown, and will, I think, continue to grow in popularity.
During my entire career at the City College of New York, I engaged in all
athletic 'sports,—baseball, football, and lacrosse; and in my graduating year
Was captain of the lacrosse team, succeeding Jack Curry, who, I believe, once
coached Hopkins. Our team that year won the championship, and many of
Our League games were veritable "hair-raisers." In our game with Lehigh we
were defeated, and previous to that game the New York Athletic Club had
beaten Lehigh, so, going by comparative scores, we seemed predestined to defeat
when our turn came to play N. Y. A. C. I remember the game perfectly as one
of the fastest and best contested I ever played, and only by the hardest kind of
work did we succeed in scoring, thus defeating our rivals by the score of one to
nothing. It was flattering for me to note that on the All American lacrosse
team of 1891-92, were four of my men.
44

2

THE NEWS—LETTER.

Several times I have played against Stevens, and I must say I found them
rather rough in their style of play. My position on the lacrosse team was first
defense.
I have met several men who have contributed largely to the success of lacrosse in Baltimore. Mr. Maddren, who, I have heard, "made" lacrosse at
Hopkins, I met during his connection with the Crescents, and I became acquainted with the five Penniman boys in 1895, when, as a delegate to a convention at the Hopkins, I visited Baltimore for the first time.
Victor Mapes, who wrote my version of "Don Caesar's Return" was a Columbia man of great athletic standing, holding the American Intercollegiate
hurdle and broad jump records, His broad jump record of 22 feet 6 inches, was
only recently broken. In 1891 Mapes was president of the American Intercollegiate Athletic Association, and I was treasurer; so it seems quite a coincidence
that he and I should be associated now in our life work as we were in college
days.
After graduating from the City College of New York I entered the New
York School of Law. The same year I captained the Law School football team,
playing, at different times, end and half back Incidentally I may state that, as
far as I am aware, I was the first man to wear a rubber nose-guard on the football field. It was in a game with Fordham, where I was lined up against a
big fellow, that I donned it for the first time. I found it extremely satisfactory,
inasmuch as I was spared the pain of a broken nose, though I must confess that
nose-guard felt awkward at first, and the astonishment created among both players and spectators was really amusing. It was in the same year, 1892, in a
game against Rutgers that I sustained a severe injury which confined me to the
hospital for two months, and it was during this period that I finally determined
upon the stage as my life career.
College dramatics always proved of much interest to me, and I always entered into them with great spirit. We had a strong number of men at the C.
C. N. *Y., who showed histrionic ability, and our efforts were generally successful. Not only did we have plenty of sport getting up plays, but the real
advantage as training for the stage was remarkable. The benefits derived from
a college dramatic society are well worth any trouble necessary in organization.
Besides the college dramatic society to which I belonged, I was also a member
of nearly every amateur club in New York for five years.
In addition to the academic training afforded by my college career, I consider the time spent there as valuable in laying a broad foundation for my life
work, and I look back upon my college days as pleasant and well spent.''

JAMES K. HACKETT.
THE PERSECUTION OF MAN.
—

t

HE powers of Smith College have shown a remarkable amount of acuteness
and ability to understand human nature in the means they have adopted
to abate, the male nuisance at the college.
There had existed a mutual admiration society between the good looking
young ladies at Smith and the good looking young men at Amherst, which re-

THE NEWS-LETTER.

3

suited in the almost eternal presence of Amherst men inside the walls of the
young ladies' seminary, not to mention innumerable little walks, and cozy little
theatre parties of two. Every Saturday and Sunday the halls of the Smith
homes were "converted into reception rooms for Amherst fellows," so that the
work for Monday—and other days—was neglected, in the pursuit of social
pleasures. Of course the education of young women should be on more serious
lines than these, so the faculty thought stringent laws were necessary. A set
of rules were consequently drawn up, which are destined to put an end to all
these frivolities. All walks, talks, and those cozy little theatre parties of two
will have to be abandoned, unless the girl is engaged to the fellow. The penalty
certainly is severe, but as students of human nature, we very much fear that the
parties concerned will not consider it in this light. It is extremely difficult for
certain people to realize the value of careful oversight by one's elders and
betters.
Later notice from Massachusetts Twenty engagements of Smith girls to
Amherst men were announced this week.

SCHOLARS AS ATHLETES.
HE prominence of athletics as a fundamental feature in college life has
grown ste dily the last few years. Probably the most patent reason for
this advancement, and the liberal acknowledgement of athletics by college
authorities, is the interest taken in sports by the scholastically inclined as well
as by the so called "athletes." Each year the records show a large number of
men carrying off academic honors, and winning athletic glory at the same time.
Here at Hopkins a glance will suffice to support this statement; some of the
best men on the football, track, and lacrosse teams are honor men, and leaders of
their respective classes. At Columbia, last year, the report of the dean showed
that twenty prominent athletes were among those receiving high academic
honors, and at all the other colleges statistics point the same way. The reason
for this is apparent, and is powerfully stated in the famous definition of education given by Thomas Huxley.
"That man, I think, has had a liberal education, who has been so trained
in his youth that his body is the ready servant of his will and does with ease
and pleasure all the work that, as a mechanism, it is capable of; whose intellect
is a clear, cold, logic engine, with all its parts of equal strength, and in smooth
working order; ready, like a steam engine, to be turned to any kind of work,
and spin the gossamers as well as forge the anchors of the mind; whose mind
is stoied with a knowledge of the great and fundamental truths of nature and
of the laws of her operations; one, who no stunted ascetic, is full of life and
fire, but whose passions are trained to come to heel by a vigorous will, the
servant of a tender conscience; who has learned to love all beauty, whether of
nature or of art, to hate all vileness, and to respect others as himself."

THE NEWS—LETTER.
WITH THE AID OF GEORGE ADE AND APOLOGIES TO
THE AFORESAID.
NCE there was a Time when this University had not Yet been moved to
Homewood, because the last Thirty-Nine cents of an Endowment was
Hard to Raise from the people of Baltimore. During this Period there
existed In Two Classes of the University a Feeling that each one was Better
than the Other, and it was often demonstrated that Such was the Case.
The facts were that One of these Classes had been Hauled over the Rough
Road of Book learning for a Year, while the other was a Young Infant, and had
just entered the Race for Knowing Things. For this reason the Former imagined
that they were Hellers ad Libitum of the Neighborhood, and that the Other Class
should do Fealty to Them; consequently, a spirit of Hostility Existed until Something had to be Decided. There being a Precedent that Such Feelings should be
settled by a Football game, and in Case Some were alive after this was Over, a
Cane rush should be instituted whereby the Rest might be killed without anyone
being Arrested for Manslaughter. These Classes decided that it was Up to Them
to do This.
When the Seventh Day of December, being the appointed time for the Killme quick, had arrived, the Junior Aggregate feeling that They were too much of a
Second-to-None to be Hauled on the Baltimore Consolidated, procured the money
somehow to Hire a Bus, or, maybe it is not Paid for yet; we don't know. It is
said, that the Freshmen were actuated by an Impulse to do the Same, but That
was All. Anyhow, they all got There.
Before any definite Steps of Procedure were taken, Both teams let their
Phisiognomies be Photographed, so that Mother might see how Brave her Boy
looked before he was Served up to her on a Stretcher. After this they Backed
up opposite each other, and got Ready to do Biz. The Junior team felt from the
Beginning that they were to be Leading Lady during the whole Matinee, and went
at it in a King Midas sort of Way that suggested that Every time they Landed,
Touchdowns could be Seen.
But there was One among the Other Team who had Some Nerve with him and
was Willing to Work. The Rest of the Team felt that He would give them a
happy Issue out of All their afflictions if he Could, and Helped him with all their
Heart. There were, on the Other hand,some ancient Aniniases among the Junior
Team, who could identify Themselves as Handlers of the Pigskin as it Should be
Handled, and inteuded to Go Way up behind the Goal posts with the Ball and Sit
down, when they Felt like it.
Alas, for these Gridiron Terrors! One Ham Jr. had rubbed some kind of
Salve into the oval,till it was Greasy as a Yard of Free Lunch,and had a Tendency
to play Hide and Seek with itself. The Juniors were frequently "It."
During the first Half both Teams avoided the Goal Posts with such Precision
that when time was Up there were no Touchdowns pinned to the Jackets of Either.
But in the second Semi, the Juniors saw that their Reputation was at Stake, and
began to Pass the Pigskin up the Line at a frequent Rate, till two Touchdowns
and almost a Third was the Result of their Rushes. When the Agony was Over,

O

THE NEWS—LETTER.

5

the Junior Ensemble could count Twelve Points for themselves, and the Freshites gave Evidence of That tired Feeling, and seemed to be Satisfied.
In the Meantime, one of the Ancient order of Cop, with a Paunch that
Helped-to make Milwaukee-famous, had a Bad Dream, and began to do some
Duty on a Junior who had done Nothing, and said to him, Come with Me.
When this Ward-heeler reached the Station with his Victim, amid Shouts of
derision, which didn't seem to Phrase him, He was Told that he Bore about the
same relation to the Force as the Appendix does to the Human Anatomy, and it
was True. The Prisoner had now Become a Hero, and had Sympathy served up
to him in large Hunks. Maidens in the Grandstand Heaved heavy Sighs, Rolled
their Eyes Heavenward, and Said, Poor Mr. Bryan; isn't Thatjust Awful!
But the Cane rush couldn't be Stopped on his Account, and the two Classes
faced each other Desperately, with a Sigh of Regret that Such indeed was the Case.
When the whistle Blew, the Carnage began, and Many a Spectator's Soul
within him Burned to see the Exploits of those so Young. They Connected with
a Crash, and many a Wretch at the Bottom of the Heap was heard to Curse unseen, and waste his Profanity on the Desert Air. Some who were so Unfortunate
as to Ring in a Little Late, leaped around on top of the Heap and Dished out
Courageous Words to their mates Below.
When enough Time was given for Those Underneath to be planted in Soil
and to Realize what a H— on Earth was, the whistle Blew again, to Show that
it was All over and the Ambulance Corps was in Order.
Later, it was Found that Eleven hands gripped the cane. Nine of these were
Traced to Grease Spots in the Ground,which were Analyzed and found to Contain
the Essential Elements of Juniority. The other two were Followed to a wisp of
Hair in the Soil, and found by a Reductio ad Absurdum to have Originally grown
on the Pate of the Dickey bird. Now that It was Over, everybody seemed to be
Happy again, and, with the Exception of two or three Stray ears, and a Sprinkling of Teeth—which were Identified and Claimed—nobody was Hurt, and all
were glad that Some one had Won. Happy youth who could Say that he was
three layers Deep under the Cane, and would have had a Hand on it if —. But
the details are Many.
The Victors again Mounted their Haul-me-Home and Travelled down the
Street, giving Everybody the Glad Glance, while the Vanquished were Happy to
Hear themselves Praised by Female admirers, and the Dickey bird could have
Had Several feminine Hearts to Do as he Pleased with if Some overheard Snags
of Conversation were Correct.
On the Whole no one was Sorry that he had been There. It was Suggested
that the Absence of a Coin grabber at the gate would Account for the numerousness of Wistful Watchers present, but Anyone who brought Friends with him
would say This was a Lie, if you accused him of It.
Moral. Freshmen—Eat Mellen's Food and grow Strong.
Juniors—Bluff them now for it is your last Chance.
Seniors—Ignore both.
L. C. M. '02.

T HAS become almost a daily occurrence to read of the vast sums of money
given away in this country for the purpose of endowing colleges. Only
last week we were astonished to read of an offer, made by Andrew Carnegie, of ten million dollars for the purpose of founding a National University,
and the very same paper informed us that the total value of gifts made by Mrs.
Stanford, to Leland Stanford University, amounted to twenty-five millions.
While we congratulate the latter University upon its good fortune, we cannot
but feel somewhat grieved over the apparent indifference manifested by Baltimoreans toward the Johns Hopkins University. Nearly a year ago two public
spirited gentlemen of this city presented our University with a valuable tract of
land, to be used as a site for new buildings, upon the condition that an endowment fund of one million dollars be raised. As yet this money has not been
forthcoming in spite of all the efforts made by the President and Trustees of the
University, to appeal to the generosity, public spirit, and patriotism of Marylanders, and especially Baltimoreans. These citizens seem utterly blind to the
fact that by aiding the University they will be advancing their own interests,
and furthering the cause of humanity and civilization. The Johns Hopkins
University is to-day a source of untold wealth and honor to this city and this
state, and yet take away the support of a few of our loyal and most devoted
supporters—a handful of men who have given their time, talents, and money to
the furtherance of higher education at our University—and we might as well be
on the other side of the ocean for all the interest taken in us, and encouragement and aid given us by the rest of Baltimore. Truly a "prophet is not with-

HE NEWS-LETTER calls special attention to the leading article in this issue,

Z

by the, famous American actor, Mr. James K. Hackett. During Mr.
Hackett's recent visit to Baltimore, as "Don Caesar de Bazan," he very
kindly consented to furnish us with a leading article relative to his college days,
and more particularly to his athletic career, while at the C. C. N. Y. This
article, by one who has been an all-round athlete, and who has excelled in lacrosse
and football, cannot fail to interest the student body. Mr. Hackett, with his
superb physique, manly bearing, and frank cordiality, is one of the finest types
of the American college man; a representative of that class of college men who,
of late years, have brought themselves to the very top of the ladder in every
calling. Moreover Mr. Hackett possesses in abundance that most admirable
quality, college spirit, for, notwithstanding the fact that he has been out of college, and deeply engrossed in his dramatic work for nearly ten years, his college days are not forgotten, and to-day he discusses with vivacity and interest
the lacrosse and foot ball battles he fought and won ten years ago. So we take
pleasure in presenting our readers with an article by him who to-day stands in
the foremost rank of the world's actors, and who is perhaps almost as well
known by the name of Rudolph Rassendyl as by his own name, James K.
Hackett.
T LAST forensic interest at Hopkins has manifested itself to the point of
intercollegiate debates. The question has been agitated a number of
times but never before has it taken definite shape. Now it is highly
probable that next spring will witness, besides our annual Junior-Senior
debate, a debate with some university of recognized standing, perhaps the
University of South Carolina. There is every reason in the world why Hopkins should indulge in these debating contests, just as all other colleges do;
but at the same time it is equally important that the adversary we choose
should be a first-class college or university—a foe, in every sense, worthy of
our steel. Our failure in the past to arouse sufficient interest among the student
body to enable us to participate in intercollegiate debates, has been the cause of
some wonder and comment among other colleges. This year our undergraduate
department has evinced a desire to inaugurate the plan. It is an excellent idea,
and should receive the hearty support of both faculty and students. Hopkins
certainly produces debating talent qualified to meet that of any other university. Already we have received a number of proposals to debate for colleges
and universities, north and south, and it only remains for us to use discrimination in choosing an antagonist.

HE NEWS-LETTICR submits to its readers the following letter, and asks for
an expression of opinion upon the subject. The writer appears to be
justified in his objection to "piling up," and though we have not considered the matter deeply, we think his suggestion good.

t

To THE NEWS-LETTER.

MR. EDITOR:
Can you suggest through the columns of your paper a substitute for our annual canerush; something by means of which future Junior and Freshman classes may be enabled
to work off their exuberant spirits. Last year, and year before last, I participated in the
rush, and this year, being a Senior, I looked on. From both observation and experience
(for both years I happened to be near the bottom of the pile) I am of the opinion that,
owing to the number of students which participate in it, the annual cane-rush is too dangerous a sport to be continued. Two years ago the president of our class had two ribs
broken in the rush, this year the president of the Freshman class was picked up unconscious, and such injuries will frequently result when some seventy or eighty men are piled
up on one another in a writhing, struggling mass. It is absolutely necessary to have some
general melee in which all members of both classes may participate, but why not substitute
something which will not necessitate nearly a hundred men piling upon one another, for
those at the bottom must suffer. I would suggest ;a flag-fight which would be just as spirited, last a little longer, contain all the elements of a class "scrap," and still avoid the
piling-up of an organized cane rush. What is the opinion of the student body?
A SENIOR.

ITHIN the next few weeks there will be at least one vacancy, and perhaps two or three, upon the staff of editors, and these vacancies will be
filled from the Junior and Freshman classes. We strongly urge that
those men desiring a place upon the paper, begin handing in specimens of their
work at once. These should be in the form of accounts of concerts or games,
original matter, or any items of university news which may interest the student
body. The Freshman class in particular we urge to exert themselves along
this line.

TO AN OLD PHOTOGRAPH.
'Tis through a mist of years I gaze at thee,
Sweet vision of the days that are no more,
While mem'ries fond and fancies odd and free
Breathe softly from the old times' golden shore.
I seem to hear thy voice so sweet and true,
To feel the tender pressure of thy hands,
And see the lovelight in those -eyes of blue
That speak of azure skies in far-off lands.
Ohl heart of hearts, would that thou now were here
To cast thy spell of love o'er ev'ry fear,
To guide my soul from earth's dark, dreary way,
From sorrow's night to hope's bright dawning day.
R. F. C., '02.

Elgin R. L. Gould, Ph. D. of the University in 1886, has been placed on
the slate for City Chamberlain of New York under the Low administration. Dr. Gould has done fine work for Low in his two campaigns; in
the recent one he was treasurer of the Committee on Finance, and collected over
$160,000 for the campaign fund. Dr. Gould is independent in politics.
Dr. George B. Shattuck, of the geological department, is president of the
newly organized Field Foray Club, the purpose of which is the study of the
natural and geological history of Maryland and adjoining regions. The 341
members of the club are mostly public school teachers taking the University extension lectures at the Hopkins.
Friday night, December 20, Dr. W. H. Tolman, director of the New York
Museum of Social Economy, will deliver a lecture in McCoy Hall on "Social
and Industrial Betterment," under the auspices of the Woman's Club of Roland
Park.
Dr. Remsen has been invited to make the leading address at the laying of
the corner stones of the two new buildings now being erected at Caylor University, Waco, Texas.
Ira Remsen, '97, Dr. Remsen's elder son, has made a hit in Paris by a portrait of the Marquis Ito, of Japan, who was recently published in the "Monde
illusive." The Marquis considered the likeness so excellent that he wrote a
Japanese poem to accompany it,besides signing the portrait in English, Chinese,
and Japanese characters. Mr. Remsen has lately returned to Paris, to resume
his art work there, from a year's service in the U. S. A. in the Philippines.
Dr. J. H. Hollander was in Boston on the .2th and 13th, for the purpose of
addressing the National Civil Service Reform League on the subject of "Insular
Civil Service." He was much missed by his undergraduate class in Economics.
Dr. D. C. Gilman has been re-elected President of the Civil Service Reform
League in New York.
At the annual banquet of the New England Alumni Association, held in
Boston last Saturday night, there were present from the University President
Remsen, Ex-President Gilman, and Dr. J. H. Hollander.
Elliott Strouse, '02, has left the University and has gone to Indiana, to
recuperate from an attack of sickness.
Eben C. Hill, '02, is recovering from a severe attack of pleurisy and typhoid
fever. He is at present free from the fever, but is left very weak by it, and will
not be out for a month.

MUSICAL CLUBS.

DN December 13 the annual concert of the Musical Clubs, at Hannah Moore
Academy, took place. The only appearances preceding this had been at
the Hospital, November 30, and at St. Mary's Parish, Roland Park, on
December 6th, so that the occasion was, as always, very enjoyable. The feature of the evening was the soloists and the duet: T. K. Gillman, of the Medical School, bass solos; S. T. Mason, '02. humorous bass solos; W. B. Carver,
G., tenor solos; and a vaudeville duet by C. S. Hodges, '98, and S. T. Mason,
which was the hit of the evening, successfully "rough-housing" the audience.
All the clubs showed up well, especially the Banjo club; and with some hard
work, the performance on the Christmas trip ought to be creditable.
After the concert a sumptuous feed was demolished, and then the reception
began. Although said one hour, it seemed scarcely ten minutes before the sad
news came that the car was waiting.

O

debaters of no little ability, and, whatever the question, the arguments
should be exceptionally good. Those men who have entered their names as
candidates for the senior and junior teams are:
Seniors—Harvey B. Stone, Charles Ma/ken, John G. Campbell, Ross M.
Diggs, J. R. Pels, B. Swayne Putts, Guggenheimer, Murphy, McGlone, Wolman, Kirk, Strouse and Myers.

AMONG THE COLLEGES.
ALE cleared $70,000 on her foot ball season.

P

Mr. Richard Sheldon whose work on Yale's track team, of which he was
captain, has given him fame all over this country, has been compelled, through
sickness, to retire from college.
In addition to general dramatic productions, both Yale and Harvard have
two or three plays a year in French and German by students in these departments.
The Yale Musical Clubs this year number about 65 men. The clubs have
so far had a successful season, both from the musical and financial points of
view.
A new and excellent regulation at I,eland Stanford University limits the
number of women students to 500.
Of 11,000 living graduates of Yale, 9000 were present at the recent Bi-centennial, representing classes from 1850 to 1901. This is the same spirit which
prompted about fifty Hopkins men to brave the rain and wind in order to witness a championship foot ball game!
The New York Tribune gives the following selection for an All-American
football team: Center, Holt, of Yale; guards, Warner, of Cornell, and Barnard,
of Harvard; tackles, Cutts, of Harvard, and Bunker, of West Point; ends,
Henry, of Princeton, and Davis, of Princeton; quarter-back, Daly of West
Point; half-backs, Weekes, of Columbia, and Kernan, of Harvard; full back,
Graydon, of Harvard. This gives Harvard four men, Yale one, Princeton two,
West Point two, Cornell one, and Columbia one.

The formation of the three cornered league with Hopkins, Lehigh, and Swarthmore as its members urges the men on all the more, and the outlook is rather

play the game; Bertram Bernheim will again have opportunity to show how he

SANTA CLAUS HEARS FROM A FRESHMAN.
EVERAL days ago the NEWS-LETTER was fortunate enough to get hold
of one of the letters which the freshmen are now sending to Santa Claus.
We feel sure that its contents will interest most of our readers.

p

DEAR SANTA CLAUS:
I have almost reached the age when boys stop writing you a list of their
wants, but there are several things I want particular bad this Christmas, and
I'm going to write to you once more. Since this time last year I've been through
some fearful trials and hardships. I worked hard all the spring and managed
to pass enough examinations to get in the Johns Hopkins University. I
thought it was grand. You know it makes you feel fine to go to Hopkins.
(There are a crowd of fellows there, though, who haven't the first rudiments of
common politeness, and instead of welcoming me in a hospitable manner, they
treated me like a little yellow dog.)
I went down there to study, and didn't propose to stand for any roughhouse, but they made me take off my hat,—sometimes my shoes, pushed me
head first out of the elevator, forced me to buy chocolate at the slot ma-

THE NEWS-LETTER.

16

chine, and insisted upon making me do the hoola-hoola dance on the trophyroom table. Now you know that wasn't fair. It wasn't wright.
Upon entering the university, I considered myself a man, and felt that I
ought to shave; so I bought a mug and put it in the barber shop. The nasty,
mean things took it, and a few days afterward, made me stand on the lockers
under the gymnasium, lather one of my fellow classmen out of my own mug,
and shave him with the butt end of a golf stick. Then he shaved me the same
way. I was so angry I most cried. But what could I do with the horrid
creatures jeering at me and telling me not to whimper?
These are only a few of the mean tricks, hut I think they are enough to
make you pity me and put what I want in my stocking.
I am awful anxious to wear a black and blue jersey, hut haven't dared to
do it yet; for I saw the juniors jerk one off a fellow's back so fast that I thought
his arms would come too. After Christmas, though, I think they will let us
wear them, so please bring me one. I wear boy's size, No. 22.
I really think I am big enough to begin smoking, but hardly know whether
it would be healthy for me or not. You might bring me a pipe and I'll wait a
few weeks before using it. I also want a cow bell for Christmas. Next year I
am going to ask you to bring me a cane. Please bring me these, Santa Claus.
I haven't had a very good time since September.
A FRESHMAN.
The unfortunate freshman who wrote the above can hardly be blamed for
saying that the treatment received at the hands of the juniors was not "wright."
He has evidently been one of the marks.
We are glad to know that he is "awful anxious" to wear a black and blue
jersey, and hope he will not be molested after Christmas for so doing.
Let him take hope in the thought that better times are coming.

HE monthly meeting of the Executive Council was held Wednesday,
December 11, at 5 P. M.

The report of the Bible Study committee for November showed an average
weekly attendance of 30 for the Bible classes.
The membership report showed a total membership of 231.
Mr. Robert E. Speer, of New York, will speak on Sunday, January 19, at
4.30 P. M.
Levering Hall Chapel was filled to its utmost on Tuesday, December 3,
when those present heard an inspiring address by Rev. S. Bates Cadman, D,D.,
of Brooklyn, on "Faith."
The men of the University owe it to themselves to come out to hear the
prominent speakers whom from time to time address the Association.

Central—This "home of the muses" receives so much patronage from all
students who possess a love for the artistic side of nature, that comment is
unnecessary. It fills a position in Baltimore parallel to the Corcoran Gallery in
Washington. We append a few rules of the house:
1. You are requested to patronize our polite attendants. 2. You are requested to report to the bouncer any inattention on the part of the ushers. The
bouncer will see that you are promptly attended to. 3. Don't throw our glassware on the floor after you have finished examining its interior. It costs
money. 4. Leave your valuables at the ticket office before entering. The
house needs the money. 5. Refrain from making remarks about the actors or
actresses while the show is going on. Don't interrupt the soubrette while she
sings.
